A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires

- Pioneer marriage
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneer in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person submitting this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have will not apply to your experiences whereas may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answering questions in a manner which is not sufficient. Please be sure to answer all questions to the best of your ability.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer life in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate pieces of paper for a separate questionnaire.

   - 1887-1888: Rossorussel, Q.S.S.A., N.W.T.
   - 1888-1889: Rossorussel, Q.S.S.A., N.W.T.
   - 1889-1890: Rossorussel, Q.S.S.A., N.W.T.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.):
   - I was 41 years old. (Aug. 11, 1841 - died April 1st, 1940)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Came west on a better chance of developing and providing for a wife and three children.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    - Through other people & government information.

You a few land rent for any no particular reason.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (school districts)

Post offices, villages, railroads, etc., were named by the originators of the name and occupation of person suggesting place-name. Any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change.

New names above in (1), (2), (3).
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, a few had moved for various reasons.

35. Did many people move away during the war years?

Some families left for their work and about 50% returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Kathryn was the Town of Brownsville School from 1887 to 1916.

Road Overseer from J. Davis to 1918.

Methodist Church Sunday School teacher from 1905 to 1918.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have done something in the district mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

The first automobile in the district was purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Smith in October 1916. Also, the first telephone was installed in the district in 1916.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School, post office, etc.)

Post offices, villages, and other places were named after prominent citizens.

39. Post offices, villages, and other places were named after prominent citizens.

40. Any other comments or observations?

Post Office: The district was named by the town council members who lived there.

School: The school was named after the town's founder.

Church: The church was named after the town's first minister.
